Acoustic waves propagating in the wind can become non-linear and
shock heat the wind.We model this shock heating via an effective
damping length prescription. Wave heating will only begin when
the waves steepen into shocks and begin to dissipate their energy.
Mihalas (1984) provides an integral expression for the
radial distance at which this takes place:
\frac { 1 } { 4 } ( \gamma + 1 ) c _ { s } ^ { - 1 } \int _ { 0 } ^ { r } u _ { 0 } ( r ^ { \prime } ) d r ^ { \prime } = \frac { \pi c _ { s } } { 2 \omega }
is the amplitude of the velocity perturbation of the
isthe adiabatic index of the background material.Here
represents the angular frequency (in the lab frame)
of thewaves.We then find the condition for shock formationto be
\int _ { 0 } ^ { r } \sqrt { \frac { \omega S } { \rho } } d r ^ { \prime } = \frac { 2 \pi c _ { s } ^ { 2 } } { \omega ( \gamma + 1 ) } .
